author: Sun Tzu
summary: There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must not be attacked, towns which must not be besieged. The general who understands the advantages of variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. Prepare for the enemy's attack rather than hoping it won't come.
key_takeaways: Some roads should not be followed, some armies not attacked, some commands not obeyed.
The wise leader blends considerations of advantage and disadvantage.
Rely on your own readiness, not on the chance that the enemy won't attack.

questions.question: What does Sun Tzu say about commands of the sovereign in certain situations?

options.text: All commands must always be obeyed without question
Some commands of the sovereign must not be obeyed if they lead to disaster
Only obey commands you agree with

questions.explanation: Sun Tzu lists 'commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed' among things that should sometimes be avoided, recognizing that rigid obedience can lead to disaster when circumstances demand flexibility.

questions.question: Sun Tzu identifies five dangerous faults in a general. What is the underlying theme connecting recklessness, cowardice, hasty temper, delicacy of honor, and over-solicitude for his men?

options.text: Extreme character traits create predictable weaknesses that enemies can exploit
Only perfect people should be generals
These faults are acceptable in peacetime

questions.explanation: Each of these faults represents an extreme that creates predictable vulnerabilities: recklessness leads to destruction, cowardice to capture, hasty temper can be provoked, sensitivity to shame can be manipulated, and over-care for soldiers exposes one to worry.

questions.question: Sun Tzu advises: 'Rely not on the likelihood of the enemy's not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him.' How does this principle apply to business risk management?

options.text: Assume competitors will never attack your market position
Build resilience and prepare for competitive threats rather than hoping they won't materialize
Focus only on offense, never defense
Risk management is unnecessary if you're the market leader

questions.explanation: This principle advocates for preparedness over hope. In business, this means building competitive moats, maintaining cash reserves, and developing contingency plans rather than assuming market conditions will remain favorable.
